items.content_html:
The description of start angle is incorrect. It starts at the right, not the top.

I thought I misunderstood something when I read this article. After testing the function on codepen, I concluded that this is a small typo.

items.content_html:
Description

The keyCode keyboard event is deprecated see KeyboardEvent.keyCode, so I updated the code snippet and preceding instructions to use e.key instead of e.keyCode. I tested this locally in my own project first, and there is no change to the expected functionality.

Motivation

This code example of tabs is awesome, especially the keyboard functionality to reach accessibility standards. Making web functionality as globally accessible as possible should be a top priority for web developers. In order to encourage that effort, developers should be confident that the accessibility-friendly code examples they find on trusted sources like MDN are valid. Keeping the code updated without any deprecated code pieces will help build that trust üåè üåç üåé

Additional details

Toptal's key checker is really helpful to quickly get the names of keys and map old keyCode values.

Related issues and pull requests

None known.
items.title: Update the tablist "keydown" event listener code to remove deprecated pieces

items.content_html:
Description

This PR makes fixes for the review comments by @wolenetz included in #22327.

Specifically, I have:

  • Updated the srcObject page to fix the note at the top, making it accurate for the current situation
  • Fixed the code examples and descriptions as suggested, in all pages that they appear.
  • Made it clear that handle is only accessible from dedicated workers.
  • Made other assorted fixes to the text.
  • Verified that the "available in web workers" links are working ok (yes, these are just broken in the previews, as only previews of changed pages are generated)

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #22327
items.title: making fixes for wolenetz review comments

items.content_html: There are 35 pages in which "Property attributes" window is below Interactive Example and 4 pages in which "Property attributes" is above. For example Infinity page has "Property attributes" placed first, while in globalThis its the opposite. I have moved Property Attributes window in those 4 pages, so order is uniform.
items.title: Move "Property attributes" window below Interactive Examples

items.content_html:
Description

This PR provides docs for the WebTransport API data. You can see more details about my work in my research document

Review status: awaiting tech review from a Chromium SME.

A couple of notes:

  1. I'm not really sure about my example on the WebTransportError pages. I thought my example would return a WebTransportError, but error.source and error.streamErrorCode return undefined.
  2. I'm still not quite sure if the chunks transmitted by the WebTransport.incomingUnidirectionalStreams ReadableStream are of type WebTransportReceiveStream, or whether these are just ReadableStreams for now. It doesn't matter hugely for the examples given, as the effect is the same either way, but it is hard to text, and it'd be good to get this right.

Motivation

High profile new API for developers to learn about.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #22281
items.title: adding docs for WebTransport

items.content_html:
Description

This PR does some cleaning on the user timing methods of the Performance interface with the goal to provide better example code.

Motivation

openwebdocs/project#62

Additional details

  • I'm not quite sure how I feel about the large return value section on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Performance/measure#return_value. It's not wrong, but is it useful?

Related issues and pull requests

mdn/browser-compat-data#18216 is a BCD PR to change "returns undefined" on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Performance/measure#browser_compatibility. I think it is backwards and that is confusing. It should be "Returns PerformanceMeasure" which is the new behavior which has new browser versions then.
items.title: Clean up User Timing methods

Bug 1740608 has amended the way in which error information is reported from scripting.executeScript() ‚Äì the error property returned now represents the value the script throws or rejects with.

items.content_html: I think stopping at "auto" is somewhat misleading; the first time I read this, I interpreted it as meaning that the percentage would simply result in the intrinsic size being used, when in fact the calculated resultant size of the grid is used with the percentage.
items.title: Added some explanation from the CSS spec for clarity

items.content_html:
Description

Updates the documentation for the action.openPopup API following changes across browsers, including the Firefox changes in https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D139796.

I've removed the note about user gesture requirements from the main body since this does not apply in any other browser (see https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xzuw1dMuf5Lub8UPME2zjxyp3nCKXk-3jtSY2kdI-FQ/edit?usp=sharing for Chrome) or Safari. Instead I've added it as a compatibility note in mdn/browser-compat-data#18202.

All browsers now also support a windowId parameter so I've added documentation for that.

Motivation

I've been working on this API recently and want to make sure the documentation is an up to date point of reference.

Additional details

  • Announcement in WebKit release notes: https://webkit.org/blog/12522/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-142/
  • Chrome proposal: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xzuw1dMuf5Lub8UPME2zjxyp3nCKXk-3jtSY2kdI-FQ/edit?usp=sharing
  • Firefox bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1755763

Related issues and pull requests

Depends on: mdn/browser-compat-data#18202
items.title: Document changes to action.openPopup API

items.title: Document two Sec-CH-* Client Hint headers

items.content_html:
Description

Add a section to the page on runtime.Port, regarding the lifecycle of a Port.
This addresses the facts that:

  • Ports can be disconnected in response to various events, and
  • these circumstances can differ between Firefox and Chrome.

Motivation

I discovered there can be subtle differences in the conditions under which a Port may become disconnected, in Firefox versus Chrome. Knowing this could save extension developers a lot of headache, and I didn't find any existing mention of it in the docs.

Additional details

  • Here is a demonstration of one surprising way in which Ports can become disconnected, when a single recipient unloads.
  • QUESTION: How much does the above demo generalize? In my test, the closing of an options page caused the disconnection. Is it true that the unloading of any single recipient is enough?
  • QUESTION: Is this actually intended behavior, or a bug? I.e. does Firefox really want its behavior on this matter to differ from that of Chrome? It would be great if a Firefox developer could weigh in.
  • I've written the new section as a stub. Ideally, it would be as complete as Chrome's corresponding section.
items.title: Add section on Port lifecycle
